abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            with project sustainability likely. The overall performance
            of both the World Bank and the Borrower are rated
            satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned included the
            following: Targeting: More attention should be devoted to
            improve targeting even when poverty is pervasive. An
            important is the application of transparent and objective
            selection and allocation criteria. Several approaches can be
            envisaged: When no poverty map is available, a standard
            allocation formula for districts and communes can be
            introduced as this would increase predictability for local
            governments and communities. Finally, communes could be
            classified into three to five categories of poverty to
            allocate a little more to poorer ones. When poverty data is
            available, targeting can be done on the basis of
            "objective" needs. In Madagascar, information is
            now available through recently completed data sources such
            as the poverty map or the commune census on local
            infrastructure endowments and economic potentials.
            Monitoring and Evaluation: While the Social Development Fund
            (FID) collected abundant information on project
            implementation, the lack of counterfactual and baseline data
            presents a number of challenges for analyzing the impact.
            Good data collection should therefore be paired with good
            methodology and a clearer evaluation strategy. Surveys on
            the operation and maintenance of the completed sub-projects
            should be preformed regularly and remedial actions should be
            taken in a timely manner.  Sustainability:. Creating
            maintenance committees is not sufficient to ensure
            sustainability of community sub-projects. More permanent
            efforts have to be devoted to ensure that these associations
            continue to function after sub-project completion. In
            addition, social funds should develop more binding
            agreements and cooperative arrangements with line agencies
            in order to ensure that commitments for the operation of
            infrastructure are respected. Ultimately however, only
            sector policy dialogue can solve this issue. The Supervision
            budget of multi-sectoral projects should reflect the
            multi-sectoral nature of these projects. Failing to do so
            may limit the impact of some category of sub-projects.
            Coordination with other sectoral Bank operations: The
            framework for coordination of the FID with rural projects
            was agreed upon and put in place but there was no follow-up.
            There should be a permanent coordination mechanism to
            maximize synergies between projects. This can take the form
            of monthly meetings of Bank and project staff for social
            sector and rural projects. However, in the long-run more
            government involvement and a more coherent national strategy
            for local development would be required to improve
            coordination on a more permanent basis. Donor Coordination:
            Efforts should be made during preparation to make social
            funds programmatic - with the social fund becoming the
            principal government vehicle for channeling various donor
            resources into local development. Although some competition
            may be good, utter fragmentation is not. Local-level
            stakeholders complain that various community development
            programs-including different Bank-funded programs-have
            different requirements (e.g. for beneficiary contributions,
            sub-project cycle etc..). Fragmented community-driven
            development donor programs also have the tendency to drive
            local development agendas rather than support them. Again,
            more government involvement, and clearer policy guidance
            would help resolve these problems on a more permanent basis.
